One candidate explanation is the difference in the 'stakes' of the outcomes between studies: in the present study, we measured changes in affect in response to relatively low-stakes rewards; by contrast, the exam outcome events studied by Villano and colleagues were likely to be much more personally meaningful to participants. It is possible that this difference might have produced a stronger effect of RPEs in the study by Villano and colleagues. However, this explanation would also accord with the present study in pointing to an additional role of decision context (in this case, outcome stakes) in moderating the strength with which RPEs influence subjective affect, as we discuss below. More broadly, we note that Villano and colleagues found that the best model of participants' affect include both grade and grade prediction error, similar to the best-fitting models from the present study. There is therefore agreement across studies that models including both reward amount and RPE outperform models with only reward amount or only RPE. Future research should assess whether the relative balance between reward amount effects and RPE effects on subjective affect is moderated by other aspects of decision context, such as the overall importance of the outcome to the individual. One way of implementing this would be to repeat the design of our study, but with higher-stakes reward outcomes. Separately, another difference in context is that students receiving their exam grades form expectations over a longer period of time, whereas participants in our studies formed expectations over shorter durations (less than 3 seconds, in most cases). Future research could also investigate the role of duration of expectation as an additional aspect of decision context that might moderate the effects of RPEs on subjective affect.

div.head: The effect of RPEs on subjective affect depends on decision context
div.p: A second aim of the present study was to investigate whether decision context moderated the effects of RPEs on subjective affect. Across two separate manipulations of decision context, we found strong evidence in favour of this proposition. Taken together, these results provide evidence that decision context alters the effects of RPEs on affect. This result is consistent with appraisal theories of emotion, but in contrast to some recent computational models of affect that do not allow for RPEs to have different effects on subjective affect in different contexts as would be predicted by recent computational models (e.g., Rutledge et al., 2014;Eldar & Niv, 2015;Bennett & Niv, 2020).

In Experiment 1, we manipulated whether participants were able to choose freely between the two choice options (free-choice trials) or had one of the two options chosen for them (forced-choice trials). Then, since the same choice options were shown in both trial types, we were able to model the effects of equivalently-sized RPEs on subjective affect separately in free-choice trials and forced-choice trials. This analysis revealed that there was a significant overall effect of negative RPEs in free-choice trials, but not in forced-choice trials. This contrasted with the effects of reward amount on subjective affect, which were significant for both gains and losses and for both free and forced-choice trials (with a slightly stronger effect of gain outcomes in free-choice trials). As such, we found that control over outcomes was a significant moderator of the effects of RPEs produced by those outcomes on subjective affect.

A moderating role for control is consistent with appraisal theories of emotion, which identify the degree of control one has over an event as being a crucial factor in the emotional response one has to that event (e.g., Smith & Ellsworth, 1985;Lerner & Keltner, 2000). Control is also implicated in a number of other affective and cognitive processes, including the assignation of blame and responsibility (Weiner, 1982), the harshness of punishment (Averill, 1982), and the evaluation of success and failure (Betancourt, 1990;Weiner & Kukla, 1970). Each of these findings implies that the degree control an individual has over an outcome may moderate the effects that other appraisals have on subjective affect, consistent with our findings.

In addition, the findings of Experiment 1 bear an interesting resemblance to findings reported by Cockburn, Collins, and Frank (2014), who found that the ability to freely choose between options amplified the effects of positive RPEs on reinforcement learning. By contrast, our findings implicated control as an important moderator of the effects of negative RPEs. It is not immediately clear why free-choice conditions might amplify the behavioural consequences of positive RPEs while amplifying the emotional consequences of negative RPEs. However, given that the effects observed by Cockburn and colleagues were specific to gain-domain outcomes (as distinct from the mixed gain-and loss-domain outcomes employed in the present study), one possibility is that the moderating effects of control on RPE processing might further depend on outcome domain (gain versus loss versus mixed). Future research could investigate this question.

In Experiment 2, we employed a different manipulation of decision context: here, participants chose freely in all trials and we manipulated whether counterfactual feedback was presented during the outcome phase of each trial. In half of trials, participants viewed the outcome of the chosen card only (counterfactual feedback absent); in the other half of trials, they were shown the outcomes of both the chosen card and the unchosen card (counterfactual feedback present). The counterfactual feedback allowed participants to learn what would have happened if they had made a different choice (cf. Palminteri, Lefebvre, Kilford, & Blakemore, 2017), but did not change the magnitude of the RPE, which depends only on the expected value of the chosen card and the outcome of the chosen card (Rutledge et al., 2014). We found that negative RPEs only influenced subjective affect when counterfactual feedback was absent; by contrast, there was no evidence for an effect of negative RPEs on subjective affect on trials in which counterfactual feedback was provided. The presence of counterfactual feedback also did not weaken the effect of the reward amount from the chosen card on subjective affect: in fact, we found that the effect of loss outcomes on affect were significantly stronger in the presence of counterfactual feedback than in its absence. It remains unclear what the underlying psychological explanation of this effect is, though it may be related to previous research showing that the mere presence of salient counterfactual information after negative feedback introduces distortions in outcome memory (Petrocelli, Seta, & Seta, 2013). More broadly, it is an open question how the effects of counterfactual feedback on subjective affect might be affected by other aspects of decision context, such as a free/forced-choice manipulation like that of Experiment 1. Future research could investigate this question.

Why might RPEs influence subjective affect only when counterfactual feedback is absent? One recent theory, the Integrated Advantage model of mood , may account for this finding. The Integrated Advantage model assumes that human mood reflects a moving average of an agent's estimates of the 'Advantage' of its recent actions, where Advantage is a quantity from theoretical reinforcement learning defined as the value of an action relative to the value of the state of the world within which the action was taken (Baird, 1994). Both counterfactual reward difference (actual minus counterfactual reward) and RPEs can be used to estimate the Advantage of an action, and as such the Integrated Advantage model can account for effects of both appraisal types on subjective affect. However, the Integrated Advantage model also predicts that the relative weight on RPEs should differ depending on whether counterfactual feedback is present or absent, because on average counterfactual reward difference is a more accurate measure of Advantage than is the RPE (see Bennett et al., 2021, pp. 520-521). As such, the Integrated Advantage model predicts that the RPE should influence affect more strongly when counterfactual information is absent, in line with the results of the present study. However, it should be noted that the Integrated Advantage model predicts this effect for both positive and negative RPEs, contrary to our findings. As such, although it can in principle account for the interaction between RPE and trial type in Experiment 2, the Integrated Advantage model cannot completely account for the results of the present study.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: Recent computational theories propose a central role for reward prediction errors in driving subjective affect. In this study, we investigated whether the effects of reward prediction errors on subjective affect differed as a function of their valence or of the decision context in which they occurred. Our results showed that both factors significantly moderated the effects of RPEs on subjective affect. In particular, after accounting for reward amount we found that only negative RPEs influenced subjective affect. Moreover, this effect of negative RPEs was present only in free-choice settings, and only where counterfactual feedback was not presented. These results extend our understanding of the role of expectation violation in subjective emotional responses. We suggest that our findings are inconsistent with the proposition that RPEs are the primary cognitive appraisal driving subjective affect.
